title: Cyclist unconscious for four days after being attacked by boy, 12
text:
Richard Smart was struck with a plastic pole and punched and kicked in the face during the savage attack (Picture: Vagner Vidal/Hyde News & Pictures Ltd/Getty Images)

A middle-aged cyclist suffered a heart attack and was unconscious for four days after he was battered by a 12-year-old boy who performed a ‘flying kick’ on him, Reading Crown Court heard.

Richard Smart was struck with a plastic pole and punched and kicked in the face when he became embroiled in a fight with a 15-year-old and two others after leaving his local shop.

He woke up in hospital battered and bruised with frontal lobe damage – which affects his short term memory – with the 15-year-old allegedly saying the attack happened because ‘he got rude to me’.

The fight started when Mr Smart came out of Simply Fresh on Northumberland Avenue in Whitley, Reading, Jai Patel, who was prosecuting, said.

A customer at the store who witnessed the confrontation said the 15-year-old had become angry with Mr Smart, telling him: ‘this is Whitley bruv, I’ll smash your windows in’.

The 15-year-old was mouthing off but the 12-year-old was nearby and didn’t say anything, the witness said.

The fight eventually escalated and the two boys picked up a long piece of cable from a house opposite the shop and approached Mr Smart, who lifted his mountain bike to defend himself until someone told him to put it down.

Mr Patel said: ‘The 15-year-old then struck Mr Smart with his plastic pole and made two, possibly three swings towards Mr Smart.

‘The 12-year-old performed what is called a ‘flying kick’ on Mr Smart from behind.

Mr Smart has been left with frontal lobe damage which affects his short term memory (Picture: Vagner Vidal/Hyde News & Pictures Ltd)

‘During that part of the incident, a third person arrives on a moped.

‘That person immediately gets off the moped, goes straight up to Mr Smart and punches him in the face with what is described as full force.’

All three then attacked Mr Smart until he was unconscious, with the 15-year-old afterwards saying things like, ‘we whacked him up’ and ‘he got rude to me’, the court heard.

The 12-year-old and 15-year-old were charged with causing grievous bodily harm without intent, which they admitted when they appeared in Reading Crown Court, then aged 14 and 16 years.

Reading from a victim impact statement by Mr Smart, Mr Patel said: ‘He feels less confident, he forgets things and that when he goes to his local shop he is worried he will see anyone involved in this incident.’

Defending the older youth, Michael Edmonds said: ‘There seem to be two sides to him: the face he likes to present to the outside world and, behind that, there is actually quite a likeable young man, but the face he presents to the outside world sometimes is not such a happy face and not such a nice face.’

The case was heard at Reading Crown Court (Picture: Google Maps)

Defending the younger boy, John Riley said: ‘He really has shown he is very sorry for what happened.

‘He seems to understand how bad it was, he wants to put it behind him and has not been in any trouble since and he is working hard to see that he stays on the straight and narrow and goes in a positive direction.’

Judge Burgess sentenced the 15-year-old – whose previous convictions included handling stolen goods, aggravated vehicle taking and a possession of a knife in a public place – to a 12-month youth rehabilitation order, with a supervision requirement.

He was also was given 60 hours of reparation and a three-month curfew added on to one he was already serving, well as a five-year restraining order preventing him from seeing Mr Smart.

The sentencing of the 12-year-old is due to take place in Reading Youth Court at a later date.

The judge told them both: ‘What you did to Mr Smart was terrible. I do not care who did what. It does not matter.

‘The three of you together – the two of you and the other person – caused him a very serious injury and are all responsible for that. You could have killed him.

The 15-year-old allegedly said ‘this is Whitley bruv, I’ll smash your windows in’ during the attack (Picture: Getty Images)

‘You may think it is easy for the judge to say that, but these things do happen. He had a heart attack. He suffered life-changing injuries.

Advertisement

‘It is easy to act tough but I expect the reality is that both of you were very scared when you got arrested. At one point, you were looking both at being locked up.

‘It is always depressing when people as young as you two are in court and I hope the court does not have to see you again.’

description: Richard Smart had a heart attack and lay unconscious for four days after he was attacked on the street, Reading Crown Court heard.
